The European Food Safety Authority reserves its rights, view and position as regards the issues addressed and the conclusions reached in the present document, without prejudice to the rights of the author(s). evidences point out interactions between environmental factors and inter-species gene regulation facilitating host control of the gut microbiota Choi et al., 2017) . However, the impact of exogenous plant ncRNAs on gut microbiota modulation remains elusive.
body_text.section: Immunophysiological role of gut microbiota

body_text.text: Increasing evidence demonstrates that a significant number of ncRNAs are found in the extracellular media, and it is apparent that mammalian cells release sRNA that might carry functions which transcend the confines of single cells (Valadi et al., 2007) . Few studies have identified changes in miRNA expression in human stool. Overall, they provide an inconsistent association between their level and dietary habits and lifestyle (Tarallo et al., 2014; . In this context, the survival of exogenous (orally administered) plant miRNAs in faeces from mice has been observed . Although the amount of particular miRNAs such as miR-172 that survived the GI tract reached a maximum of 4.5%, this study does not support consistent survival rates for distinct ncRNAs.
body_text.section: Role of ncRNAs in shaping gut microbiota

body_text.text: A recent study identified miRNAs secreted by intestinal epithelial cells in intestinal contents and supports their role in modulating gut microbiota composition . This study reports the potential of host miRNAs to enter bacteria and co-localize with microbial nucleic acids. Similarly, exogenous plant miRNAs that were present in animal faeces were indicated as being primarily acquired orally . Recently, bacterial RNAs comparable in size to miRNAs have been identified that could serve as signalling molecules mediating bacteria-to-human interaction (Choi et al., 2017) . These data were obtained from outer membrane vesicles produced by periodontopathogens and were able to exert 'slight' immunosuppressive effects on T cells cytokine production (IL-5, IL-13 and IL-15).
body_text.section: Role of ncRNAs in shaping gut microbiota

body_text.text: MiRNA expression levels and amount in stool appear to be modulated by diet (micro-and macronutrients, phytochemicals) without excluding the possibility that the results were affected by other lifestyle factors; however, the influence of GM plant exogenous ncRNAs has not yet been exhaustively studied in animals or humans.
body_text.section: Role of ncRNAs in shaping gut microbiota

body_text.text: Distinct innate immune mediators participating in the recognition and discrimination between the distinct nucleic acids have been identified; thus, additional definition of the dynamic interplay between the different 'sensors' (i.e. TLRs, RIG-I/MDA5, the interferon response effectors protein kinase R and RNase L) in response to ncRNAs have to be clarified.
body_text.section: Gaps in the literature on the effects of exogenous ncRNAs on the immune system

body_text.text: The chemical modifications observed in plant ncRNAs highlight the need to address the detection and measurement of exogenous plant ncRNAs in body fluids, as well as the sensitivity and specificity of these RNAs to cellular and tissue targets.
body_text.section: Gaps in the literature on the effects of exogenous ncRNAs on the immune system

body_text.text: Although many reports focusing on synthetic ss-and dsRNA mimics can be found in the literature, scientifically assessed direct hazardous impacts of food and feed on fauna and flora are scarce and conflicting. Notably, there is a need to evaluate the effects of exogenous plant ncRNAs at the system biology level and in human trials. Current knowledge on the immune functions of exogenous ncRNAs is comparatively lacking. Most studies use cell models based on isolated cells that could not mimick the whole set of players that determine immune response(s), which are necessary for mechanistic studies, but need approach cell-to-cell communication in target tissues. Additionally, these studies should focus on the relationship of immune responses to production of IFNs since TLRs signalling converge on the production of this immune regulatory factor.
body_text.section: Gaps in the literature on the effects of exogenous ncRNAs on the immune system

body_text.text: To better understand the impact of exogenous ncRNAs in host microbiota composition and diversity, further studies are needed to establish the microbial targets and their effect on physiological conditions.
body_text.section: Gaps in the literature on the effects of exogenous ncRNAs on the immune system

body_text.text: Understanding the basic biological aspects of plant-derived exogenous ncRNA (including their half-life and stability), gathering information on human and animal exposure by diet to these molecules, their subsequent bioavailability and possibility to exert local or systemic effects, and reviewing the experience from the development of RNA-based therapeutics are relevant aspects for the risk assessment of ncRNAbased GM food and feed.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: The literature includes very few studies evaluating the half-life of plant-derived ncRNAs. While no specific studies on plant miRNAs and lncRNAs half-life were found in this review, the studies on plant circRNAs half-life suggest that they exhibit considerable stability as compared to linear RNAs (section 3.1.2.1). In mammals, the few reports related to ncRNAs half-life suggest that miRNAs and circRNAs are generally much more stable than mRNA, while lncRNAs have a half-life like that of mRNA. However, when assessing the stability of plant ncRNAs outside the plant (section 3.1.2.2.), compelling evidence exists that plant miRNAs are highly stable under different conditions including food storage, processing, cooking, or simulated digestion. Moreover, they seem to survive after long incubation in serum, or are detected in the gastric content of mice, suggesting that plant miRNAs are more resistant to degradation than synthetic or animal miRNAs. This high resistance has been attributed to the unique characteristics of plant miRNAs (and siRNAs), in contrast to miRNAs from mammalian and other organisms; the 2'-Omethylation at their 3' end which confers plant miRNAs more resistance to degradation (section 3.1.1.1). body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: The present document has been produced and adopted by the bodies identified above as author(s). body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: The experience from development of ncRNA therapeutics (section 3.1.3) shows that unmodified nucleic acids (i.e. RNAs) exhibit very low stability in biological media and are subjected to rapid nuclease mediated degradation. Indeed, a plethora of RNases are encoded within most genomes, often with overlapping activities, making redundancy a general feature of RNA degradation systems. Consequently, different chemical modifications or conjugations have been introduced to potential RNA-based therapeutics (section 3.1.3.2) to improve their RNA-binding affinity, their in vivo nuclease stability and their pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties. The available literature also suggests that naked or unmodified RNAs parenterally administered (e.g. iv) are rapidly cleared from circulation and their presence in the kidney and urine has been reported immediately after administration (section 3.1.4). Similarly, following oral administration naked or unmodified exogenous RNAs are rapidly degraded when exposed to the GI harsh conditions, and different delivery vehicles for exogenous RNAs have been developed. In general, and in contrast to chemically modified or formulated RNAs, no major biological effects have been observed for naked RNAs, which has probably limited further evaluation in humans (section 3.1.4.7). Although certain disease conditions may influence the pharmacokinetics of exogenous RNAs, there are no studies that specifically evaluate this for naked unmodified exogenous ncRNAs.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: To exert a biological effect, an exogenous ncRNA first needs to reach the intended target tissue in sufficient quantity levels, this implying the necessity to overcome many biological barriers (section 3.1.5). Considering the oral intake as the main possible entry point of exogenous plant ncRNAs into both animals and humans, the first major barrier is the mammalian GI tract, which encompasses a group of extracellular and cellular barriers. Extracellular barriers include the presence of different enzymes (i.e. nucleases), the harsh environment and a net negative charged mucous layer. The cellular barriers include a three-layer (epithelial cells or enterocytes, the lamina propria and the muscularis mucosa) barrier known as the intestinal mucosa. Possible ncRNAs passage between cells is limited by the presence of tight junctions and the pore size in the human intestine would prevent the passage of all but miRNAs, which are the smallest ncRNAs. Although crossing the cells by transcytosis may be possible, this mechanism implies facing new intracellular barriers, such as nucleases, recycling of ncRNAs back to the lumen and nuclear uptake. However, M-cells, present in the gut epithelium interspersed between enterocytes, present certain characteristics that would make them more amenable for RNA uptake. A second barrier is represented by a set of obstacles during the passage from the intestine to the target tissue, which encompasses plasma and tissue nucleases. Once in the circulatory system, exogenous ncRNAs are subjected to distribution and elimination. For example, small RNAs would be rapidly cleared by the kidney due to their small size. Furthermore, ncRNAs need to escape the reticuloendothelial system, the function of which is to clear foreign pathogens. Finally, they would have to cross the vascular endothelial barrier to reach the target tissue, facing hurdles like those in the enterocytes. Packaging or incorporation of ncRNAs into extracellular transport systems (i.e. exosomes/microvesicles or inclusion in ribonucleoprotein complexes) would confer certain resistance to nucleases and other barriers.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: ncRNAs must enter the target cells to exert their functions. The molecular mechanisms of exogenous ncRNA cellular uptake have been inferred from studies performed when developing strategies for nucleic acids delivery as therapeutics and is also largely derived from invertebrates, with little data reported in mammals. Descriptions exist of receptor-mediated uptake of oligonucleotides through the SIDT1 and SIDT2 proteins, although this is now in doubt since they have been described as cholesterol transporters. Due to the charged nature of RNAs, cellular uptake could be achieved by endocytosis after which they would enter the system of intracellular trafficking through multiple membrane-bound compartments. ncRNAs must exit these compartments to reach their functional sublocation within the EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: cell, either the cytosol or the nucleus, while simultaneously escaping degradation in the lysosomes. Specialized barriers such as the blood-brain barrier or the placental barrier represent additional obstacles to overcome.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: While RNA content in plant-derived foods varies (≈1 mg/g of tissue), it could be estimated that when consuming a daily dose of total fruit and vegetables of ≈600 g/day, humans theoretically ingest 600 mg of total RNAs (dietary intake of plant RNA may typically range from 0.1-1 g/person/day) (section 3.1.6.1). Humans following special diets, such as vegetarians and vegans, have higher intake of plant origin RNAs, but estimated exposure to such RNAs implies only a 3-fold increase on average (section 3.1.6.2). It has been estimated that small RNAs make up far less than 5% of total RNA in plants, suggesting a very low exposure to plant ncRNAs under normal conditions. Whether sufficient levels of exogenous plant ncRNAs can be consumed in the diet to exert a biological effect is also another aspect that needs to be evaluated. Some examples in the literature suggest that for certain plant miRNAs (i.e. miR-156a) a person would need to consume 1670 kg of cantaloupe to reach the 100 copies of miRNA per cell possibly determining an effect. These aspects should be evaluated for each plant ncRNA (on a case basis), considering that some plant-derived miRNAs have shown unexpectedly high resistance to degradation and greater bioavailability.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: The available literature indicates a widespread presence of exogenous RNAs (including plant derived ncRNAs, i.e. small RNAs) in the biological fluids of humans and animals (section 3.3.2). Whether these RNAs are derived from dietary intake is unclear. Their generally low abundance and lack of enrichment in tissues mostly exposed to dietary changes (i.e. liver) suggest that some of may have be originated as technical artefacts or through contamination.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: Very few studies address biological effects of dietary exogenous ncRNAs in the GI tract and its annex glands (e.g. liver) (section 3. can directly target mammalian genes through RNAi effects, but still clarification is needed if exogenous plant ncRNAs can overcome all the biological barriers to reach and interact with their possible targets. Exogenous plant-derived ncRNAs have been found in exosomes or macrovesicles. How they reach these types of structures in biological fluids is unknown. In summary, supporting and contradicting evidence concerning the existence of systemic effects of dietary plant-derived exogenous ncRNAs is heavily debated. Important aspects such as the precise mechanism/s of transport of plant ncRNAs from food into the systemic circulation, the amount of exogenous ncRNAs reaching tissues or the molecular mechanisms of cellular uptake need to be determined.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: While several in vitro studies cover the participation of exogenous ncRNAs in the dynamic network to modulate innate immunity responses, few tackle the immunomodulatory effects of plant ncRNAs in adaptive immune response (section 3.4). None of these studies have considered the potential impact of exogenous dietary plant-derived ncRNAs at the systemic level.
body_text.section: General remarks

body_text.text: Since the first publication suggesting a possible cross-kingdom effect by dietary ncRNA (through rice miR-168a) the knowledge on exogenous ncRNAs, and particularly plant-derived exogenous ncRNAs, on EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: their fate when ingested has increased. However, the knowledge useful to support the assessment of dietary ncRNA such as ncRNA-based GM food and feed still faces several gaps.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: An important aspect needing further investigation is the stability of plant ncRNAs. The meagre available literature contains a very few studies of the half-life of plant ncRNAs (i.e. miRNAs, lncRNAs and circRNAs) both inside the plant cell and outside the plant. Specifically, the stability of circRNAs should be assessed due to their apparently high stability. Moreover, very few reports focus on assessment of plant ncRNAs stability in mammalian systems, when ingested. Understanding the molecular basis that confers plant ncRNAs stability is of great importance and needs to be further evaluated. For instance, plant miRNAs and siRNAs carry modifications that do not occur in mammals. These modifications, such as the presence of a methyl group located on the 3' nucleotide ribose, could hypothetically have an impact on the plant miRNAs stability in mammalian systems/cells due to either the lack of the appropriate enzymes for recognition and degradation of plant miRNAs by mammalian cells, or the increased stability to degradation by mammalian RNases. The circularized structure of plant circRNAs would hypothetically confer them increased stability to mammalian RNAses. If this is the case, plant miRNAs and circRNAs could exhibit a much longer half-life in mammalian systems than expected, especially when compared to mammalian miRNA or circRNAs. This would increase their chances of reaching the appropriate target tissue and encountering suitable target molecules within the cells. The half-life of plant ncRNAs within mammalian cells is also an important aspect to consider. Experiments are needed with labelled plant ncRNAs, first in transfected mammalian cells (in vitro studies) and then orally administered to experimental animals (in vivo studies). Radioactive probes or molecules of very low molecular weight, such as biotin or fluorescein, should be used, in order to prevent distorting the actual size of the studied plant ncRNA; this is important when studying miRNAs stability due to their small size.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: Another aspect possibly relevant for risk assessment is to understand whether and how ingested GM plant-derived ncRNAs can affect the expression levels of other ncRNAs and other RNAs, due to putative compensatory circuits and codifying RNAs. Whole transcriptome sequencing, comparing the RNA levels of unmodified (wild type) to those of modified (transgenic) plants coul be useful to this aim.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: Although available information suggests that many biological barriers exist in mammalian system to ingested plant exogenous ncRNAs preventing these to exert a possible local or systemic effect, several gaps are still present. Putative pathways of dietary exogenous ncRNAs after ingestion and the many transporters potentially involved (i.e, in cellular uptake, or barrier passage transport pathways) in the transit from the gut to the target tissues should be characterized using standard molecular biology gainof-function and loss-of-function approaches. Also, the many routes of mammalian intracellular trafficking to the specific intracellular target should be studied. To this aim, ncRNAs isolated from human diets should be used preferentially, since most of the incomplete current knowledge comes from the RNA-therapeutics field or is derived from the invertebrate world. Which molecular mechanisms support the possible passage through specialized barriers (i.e. blood-brain barrier or the placental barrier), is another critical aspect requiring further studies.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: While there are in vitro studies describing the interaction between plant miRNAs and mammalian miRNA silencing complexes possibly leading to target repression, these findings need to be experimentally validated in vivo. Therefore, more studies are needed to understand the possibility of processing plant ncRNAs in mammalian cells. It is also unknown if ingested plant miRNAs reaches or needs to reach a necessary level to exert a biological effect. For instance, studies in mammals suggest that the threshold for target gene regulation is >100 copies per cell for a certain study; however, another study suggests around 1000 to 10.000 copies of mammalian miRNA per cell. Clearly, a minimum amount of small RNAs EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: would be required to achieve biologically relevant effects on gene expression. On a case by case basis it would be useful to evaluate the amount of consumption of a given ncRNA in a normal diet. It is also relevant to study if exposure to these plant ncRNAs could change under certain pathological conditions (i.e. compromised intestinal permeability or renal function) or dietary patterns (i.e. vegetarian or vegan diets).
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: Although tissue accumulation of dietary plant exogenous ncRNAs has not been reported to date, it seems clear that plant miRNAs and other exogenous RNAs are present in biological fluids from humans and animals. The biological significance of their presence is still unknown and needs to be addressed. Methods that do not require amplification for detection should be used. More quantitative approaches to determine the levels of plant-derived exogenous ncRNAs should be determined both in biological fluids and tissues to understand the magnitude of presence. For example, this could be partially obtained from studies reporting the presence of exogenous RNAs in biological fluids using public small RNA-seq databases. In the case of plant-derived miRNAs, the use of sodium periodate oxidation of samples could be a good start to verifying the presence of genuine plant-derived miRNAs from diet in human and animal biological fluids.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: The immunomodulatory effects of exogenous RNAs have been widely described in the literature.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: However, there is no in vivo information regarding the immunomodulatory effects of dietary exogenous ncRNAs. These types of studies should be performed both in vitro and in vivo to determine if the different types of ncRNAs consumed in the diet can affect the immune system.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

body_text.text: In the case of target gene repression by plant ncRNAs investigations in specific animal models could be considered. Expression levels of other ncRNAs and RNAs, which may be modified due to putative compensatory circuits could be evaluated in these models, as well as information on the stability and half-life of the specific ncRNA in specific cells and systemically following ingestion.
body_text.section: Gaps in the scientific literature and recommendations

FIGREF13.text: Dicer1 flox/flox xCre/Esr1 mice were treated with 500 nM hydroxy-tamoxifen, (OHT) for 48 h. The cells were collected every 24 h from Day 3 (T = 72 h) following initial OHT addition. Selected miRNAs were measured from biological triplicates of cells stimulated with OHT, normalized to snoRNA-202 and reported at initial values at T = 72 h (i.e. Day 3 following initial OHT treatment). Grey highlighting indicates variation in miRNA decay observed between the seven miRNAs analysed, and the fitted exponential regression with halving-time is shown for miR-125b and miR-155. SEM is shown. Source: From(Gantier et al., 2011).

FIGREF16.text: marketed as Exondys 51) was also approved in late 2016 by the FDA, for treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Eteplirsen is an antisense morpholine which triggers excision of exon 51 of dystrophin mRNA, producing a functional dystrophin protein in patients with DMD. Several other RNA-based therapeutics are in advanced clinical trials (Sullenger and Nair, 2016), including aptamers Rossi, 2016), miRNAs (Adams et al., 2016; van der Ree et al., 2014), siRNAs EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

FIGREF18.text: Flanigan et al., 2014). 2'-MOE has been used in single-stranded siRNAs(Lima  et al., 2012)  and is included in a recently FDA-approvedASO (Santos et al., 2015). Several other 2'-Omodified structures have been tested in RNAi studies(Odadzic et al., 2008). 2'-Fluoro (2'-F) modification locks the sugar ring into the C3'-endo sugar pucker resulting in increased thermal stability at 2 to 3 ºC per modification, and improved RNA affinity(Pallan et al., 2011). However, 2'-F modified oligonucleotides are not nuclease resistant(Li and Rana, 2014). 2'-F is widely used in miRNA(Rayner  et al., 2011) and siRNA (Lima et al., 2012)  therapies and is also present in an FDA-approved aptamer for treatment of macular degeneration(D'Amico et al., 2006). Locked Nucleic Acid (LNA) is another chemical modification leading to a bicyclic RNA that tethers the 2'oxygen to the 4'carbon via a methylene bridge, locking the sugar furanose ring into the C3'-endo conformation(Obika et al., 1997)  (Figure 9). The LNA modification dramatically increases RNA biding affinity (≈+5 to +8 ºC per LNA) and nuclease resistance inASO, siRNAs (Mook et al., 2010; Mook et al., 2007), miRNAs(Janssen et al., 2013)  and aptamer(Schmidt et al., 2004)  therapeutics. Although fully modified LNA might reduce efficacy as well as off-target effects(Mook et al., 2007), the use of this chemical modification allowed the development of a complete tiny RNA (≈8 mers) for in vivo miRNA use(Obad et al., 2011; Rottiers et al., 2013).

FIGREF19.text: Unlocked RNA, lacking the C2'-C3'-bond of the RNA ribose ring, are compatible with the siRNA mechanism and have increased stability in vivo even when naked (Laursen et al., 2010). Several other modifications including constrained ethyl bridged nucleic acid (BNA) or stereoisomer L-LNA have been described in the literature (Wan and Seth, 2016; Sorensen et al., 2002).

FIGREF20.text: exonuclease degradation(Lennox and Behlke, 2010), restricting their in vivo applications. Indeed, the phosphodiester backbone of nucleic acids, including RNAs, is rapidly hydrolysed by nucleases in biological systems. Replacement of one of the non-bridging oxygen of a phosphodiester linkage with a sulphur (phosphorothioate) is one of the most common backbone modifications used in the current RNA-based therapeutics arsenal (Eckstein, 2014). Phosphorothioate backbones are less susceptible to nuclease cleavage in vivo and thus increase DNA or RNA stability, as has been widely observed when developing ASO therapeutics(Kastelein et al., 2006), miRNA therapeutics (Janssen et al., 2013 Esau  et al., 2006; Krutzfeldt et al., 2005), or siRNA therapeutics(Soutschek et al., 2004; Braasch et al.,  2004).

FIGREF21.text: unspecific target genes(Winkler et al., 2010)  or platelet activation(Flierl et al.,  2015).Several other backbone modifications have been studied in RNA-based therapeutics(Wan and Seth,  2016). Boranophosphonate, as a replacement of one of the nonbridging oxygen atoms of the phosphodiester linkage with boron, enhances nuclease resistance and exerts siRNA activity using singlestranded RNAs(Hall et al., 2006). Alkoxy group modification (phosphotriester) increases serum stability, confers neutral charge and they can be converted by cytoplasmic thioesterases into native, charged phosphodiester-backbone siRNAs(Meade et al., 2014). The use of nitrogen (N3'-N5' phosphoroamidate) increases resistance to nucleases and affinity toward the complementary RNA(Faria et al., 2001;  Gryaznov, 2010). Amides can also be a good replacement for phosphodiester internucleoside linkage in RNA and may increase RNAi activity when placed near the 5'-end of the passenger strand(Mutisya et  al., 2014). Replacing the sugar phosphate backbone with a peptide scaffold [peptide nucleic acid (PNA)] increases nuclease resistance but with limited solubility and poor protein binding(Egholm et al., 1993;  Wan and Seth, 2016). PNA can be used for translation inhibition(Nulf and Corey, 2004)  or as a siRNA mechanism(Gaglione et al., 2014). Phosphorodiamidate morpholinos, in which the sugar phosphate backbone is replaced with a morpholino ring and the phosphodiester linkage with a phosphorodiamidate linkage, confers very high resistance to nucleases(Hudziak et al., 1996). Although also tested for miRNA function(Chang et al., 2016), morpholinos have mainly been evaluated for exon skipping therapy(Cirak  et al., 2011). Several other additional chemical modifications, not described here, have been reported in the literature.ConjugationBecause of their size and negative charges, exogenous RNAs cannot easily cross cell membranes (see below). Moreover, chemically modified oligonucleotides, when administered in the absence of a carrier, show limited tissue distribution and are rapidly excreted in urine(Tavitian et al., 1998; Li and Rana,  2014; Moschos et al., 2011). Thus, different conjugation methods have been developed for RNAs therapeutics. Cholesterol conjugation has been shown to increase cellular uptake in several tissues as well as in vivo stability of anti-miRs (antagomirs)(Krutzfeldt et al., 2007; Krutzfeldt et al., 2005), siRNAs(Wolfrum et al., 2007; Gao et al., 2009)  or other ASOs. Lipoprotein-mediated delivery of cholesterolmodified siRNA has been proposed to increases hepatic uptake(Wolfrum et al., 2007). Palmitic acid conjugation has also been reported to be effective in vivo(Kubo et al., 2016)  for Dicer substrate siRNAsLiterature review of information supporting food/feed risk assessment of RNAi-based GM plants www.efsa.europa.eu/publications 71 EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

FIGREF24.text: based methods have been used for in vivo delivery in animal models for siRNAs(Morrissey et   al., 2005; Zimmermann et al., 2006), short dsRNA(Kabilova et al., 2016)  and miRNAs(Endo-Takahashi  et al., 2014; Ando et al., 2014), and in humans for siRNAs(Schultheis et al., 2014; Koldehoff et al.,  2007). Lipid encapsulation increases the half-life of unformulatedRNAs (Morrissey et al., 2005). Different formulations have been developed, including cationic lipids, polyethylene glycol (PEG)-lipid conjugates(Morrissey et al., 2005; Zimmermann et al., 2006); N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc), which binds with high affinity to the asialoglycoprotein receptor (ASGPR) expressed on hepatocytes (Akinc et al., 2010); or several others described elsewhere(Wu and McMillan, 2009). All these advances have led to liposomal delivery of miRNA miR-34, which is being used in clinical trials(Beg et al., 2016).Advances in material science, nanotechnology and chemical engineering have also led to development of nanoparticle (polymer)-based methods for in vivo RNA delivery(Li and Rana, 2014). A wide variety of tools have been developed leading to several therapeutics reaching clinical trials(Sullenger and Nair,  2016; Zuckerman and Davis, 2015). Chitosan polymer nanoparticles have been used to deliver siRNAs and miRNAs(Gaur et al., 2015)  both systemically and for mucosal delivery(Howard et al., 2006). Pectincoated water-soluble chitosan nanoparticles have been tested for colonic delivery of dsiRNA(Hussain et  al., 2017). Several modifications of chitosan have been developed, including galactose-modified trimethyl chitosan-cysteine conjugates for oral delivery(Han et al., 2014).Lipid nanoparticles containing siRNA have rapidly entered into clinical trials for several diseases(Dunning  et al., 2016; Suhr et al., 2015; Coelho et al., 2013; Tabernero et al., 2013). Among these, Revusiran (known as ALN-TTRSC), a GalNAc-siRNAs conjugate which targets transthyretin (TTR), has undergone clinical development (via subcutaneous route for liver diseases)(Zimmermann et al., 2017). Together with Patisiran (also known as ALN-TTR02), which also targets TTR via intravenous administration, these are the most advanced siRNA-based therapeutics to date (Zuckerman and Davis, 2015; Sullenger and Nair, 2016). Other non-lipidic nanoparticles have also been developed. CALAA-01 is a polymer-based nanoparticle coated with the human protein transferrin that targets the kidney, allowing the siRNA to reach the RRM2 gene(Zuckerman et al., 2014).

FIGREF31.text: or other RNA-based therapeutics(Zuckerman and Davis, 2015; Zuckerman et al., 2014;  Beg et al., 2016).In general, RNA-based experimental therapeutics (as exemplified by siRNAs or miRNAs) have shown dose-dependent increases in both the siRNA or miRNA maximum serum concentration (C max ) and AUC (i.e. the integral of the concentration-time curve) (Zuckerman and Beg et al., 2016). Most experimental siRNA drugs did not demonstrate dose accumulation over time, except in cases where the mononuclear phagocyte system is saturated(Zuckerman and Davis, 2015)

FIGREF32.text: Synthetic siRNAs formulated in liposomes has been shown to target the epidermis (Desmet et al., 2016). Subcutaneous delivery of siRNA in phosphate buffered saline (PBS) resulted in its presence at the www.efsa.europa.eu/publications 83 EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

FIGREF33.text: The lung (administered by intratracheal or intranasal routes or by inhalation) has demonstrated to be an effective route for in vivo administration of naked unmodifiedRNA (Lam et al., 2012). Naked siRNAs seem to be stable (in terms of siRNA integrity after nebulization) in nebulizers for inhaled pulmonary therapy(Tahara et al., 2016). Several studies have evaluated intranasal administration of naked siRNAs in mice(Senoo et al., 2010), macaques (slightly chemically modified, deoxythymidine dinucleotide [dTdT])(Li, BJ et al., 2005)  and humans (slightly chemically modified, dTdT)(DeVincenzo et al., 2010). Intratracheally administered naked siRNAs were found to be rapidly absorbed systemically and eliminated in the urine (Moschos et al., 2011), while chemically modified or formulated siRNAs were found in the pulmonary tissue or in the peripheral blood for a longer period -even hours after administration(Gutbier et al., 2010). Pharmacokinetic analysis revealed rapid transfer of siRNA molecules into the vascular system and accumulation in the kidney, questioning the lung-specificity of intratracheal administered naked siRNA (2'-O-methylated siRNA)(Gutbier et al., 2010). The literature describes other naked siRNAs tested by intratracheal(Perl et al., 2005)  or intrapulmonary administration for local therapy(Rosas-Taraco et al., 2009), although with minor chemical modifications. Non chemically modified miRNA mimicking hairpins have also been administered intranasally in mice models(Das et al., 2014).

FIGREF34.text: 1 of unmodified siRNA) (Wilson et al., 2010) or β1,3-D-glucan encapsulation (Aouadi et al., 2009) (2.3 mg kg -1 d -1 of siRNA), were found to be biologically-active and to reach target or systemic tissues in animal studies. However, direct injection of naked siRNA into the mice gut loop mucosa (in situ gut ligation model) did not result in cellular uptake 30 min after administration, while other formulated Literature review of information supporting food/feed risk assessment of RNAi-based GM plants www.efsa.europa.eu/publications 84 EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

FIGREF35.text: Dejneka et al., 2008). The radioactive half-life (radiolabelled siRNA) in the vitreous fluid exceeded 48 h. No systemic treatment-related clinical signs were observed in the rabbits following a single intravitreal dose of the siRNA (Dejneka et al., 2008). Intravitreal injection of naked siRNAs in rats elicited a long-lasting ocular biological effect (Roy et al., 2011). Two hours post-injection the siRNA was localized in the retina vascular cells and pericytes, and its effect peaked one week post-injection at a ≥1 µM concentration (Roy et al., 2011). Other research groups have not observed accumulation of naked siRNAs (5 µg injected in the vitreous) 24 h post-injection, compared to its formulated version, suggesting rapid degradation of unprotected siRNA in the vitreous (Turchinovich et al., 2010)

FIGREF36.text: Damms-Machado et al., 2017). Other pathological conditions, including hyperglycaemia(Thaiss et al., 2018)  or the presence of certain pathogenic bacteria(Manfredo Vieira et  al., 2018)  can drive intestinal barrier disruption. Moreover, human polymorphisms in C1orf106, which is associated to risk of inflammatory bowel disease(Rivas et al., 2011), regulate the integrity of intestinal epithelial cells(Mohanan et al., 2018).

FIGREF43.text: highly vascularized, with numerous immune cells), and the muscularis mucosa(O'Neill et al., 2011). The epithelial layer includes enterocytes, goblet cells, M-cells, Paneth cells, intraepithelial lymphocytes and hormone-secreting endocrine cells. RNAs could theoretically cross the epithelium either between the cells (paracellular route) or through the cells (transcellular route). The first option is limited by the presence of tight junctions between cells (Linnankoski et al., 2010). These junctions represent less than 1% of the mucosal surface area of the intestine(Jung et al., 2000). In inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), however, tight junctions permeability is increased as the epithelium is disrupted(Clayburgh et al., 2004). Paracellular pore size in the human intestine generally ranges from 0.5-3 nm (Linnankoski et al., 2010), which would theoretically barely allow passage of miRNAs, the smallest ncRNAs, which have a cross-section size of approximately 2.5 nm and a contour of 6-7 nm(Gu et al., 2012). The transcellular transport route has the advantage of presenting an extensive area for theoretical uptake(Daugherty and Mrsny, 1999). The main mechanism is transcytosis, involving endocytosis of molecules at the apical membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, their transport through the cells and across the basolateral membrane into the underlying lamina propria(O'Neill et al., 2011). Intracellular barriers include the presence of nucleases, recycling of the ncRNAs back to the lumen and nuclear uptake.

FIGREF44.text: Scheme of intestinal epithelium anatomy illustrating the associations between the epithelial barrier, systemic circulation and immune system cells. Magnification of the intestinal epithelium (bottom panel) shows its detailed structure. IEL: intraepithelial lymphocytes; TJ: tight junction. ncRNAs could gain access to the lamina propria either by the paracellular route, or via transcytosis through enterocytes or M-cells. ncRNAs could subsequently enter the circulatory system or the lamina propria cells. Adapted from(Daugherty AL and Mrsny RJ, 1999).

FIGREF53.text: Laroui et al., 2014;Xiao et al., 2014; Laroui et al., 2011). siRNAs against CD98 were electrostatically complexed with polyethylenimine (PEI)-loaded nanoparticles and encapsulated in alginate and chitosan hydrogels (ratio 7/3) for oral use(Laroui et al., 2014). Daily oral treatment (8 days) with these encapsulated nanoparticles (60 µg siRNA/kg) reduced inflammation in a mouse model of colitis(Laroui et al., 2014). Single-chain CD98 antibody (scCD98)-PEG-urocanic acid (UAC)-modified chitosan (scCD98-PEG-UAC)/PEI nanoparticles carrying siRNAs against CD98 were also shown to be effective in a murine model of colitis(Xiao et al., 2014). The siRNA nanoparticles were encapsulated in an alginate chitosan hydrogel (ratio 7/3) that selectively degraded in the vicinity of the inflamed colon (2 mg/kg siRNA per day for 4 days)(Xiao et al., 2014). The same group tested a combination therapy using the anti-inflammatory agent curcumin. A polymeric nanoparticle containing hyaluronic acid-functionalized siRNA against CD98 (siCD98) and curcumin, encapsulated into a hydrogel comprised of chitosan and alginate, was used in a model of ulcerative colitis(Xiao et al., 2016). Daily treatment with an oral dose of 5 mg/kg curcumin and 16.55 µg/kg siCD98 was efficient in a mouse model of DSS-induced colitis(Xiao et al., 2016). An alternative nanoparticle using polyethyleneimine for TNFα siRNA delivery, was found to be effective in a mouse model of colonic inflammation (Laroui et al., 2011). As above, for oral use (5 mg siRNA/mL hydrogel) the siRNA nanoparticles were encapsulated in alginate chitosan hydrogels(Laroui et al., 2011).Chitosan is a linear cationic mucopolysaccharide composed of randomly distributed N-acetyl-Dglucosamine and β-(1,4)-linked D-glucosamine. Its biocompatible, biodegradable, mucoadhesive, nonimmunogenic and non-toxic properties have led to development of polymers for oral use(Lai and Lin,  2009). Indeed, chitosan polymer derivative nanoparticles have also been used for ncRNA delivery for oral use. To improve the solubility of chitosan, trimethylation modification can be introduced(Kean et  al., 2005)  or galactosylation modification applied to increase galactose receptor-mediated endocytosis. Nanoparticles of trimethyl chitosan-cysteine containing siRNA against TNFα (2'-O-methyl modified) were evaluated for their resistance to GI biological fluids. While different formulated nanoparticles resisted incubation with intestinal fluids, intestinal homogenate and gastric fluids, naked siRNA (even slightly chemically modified) was degraded following incubation with gastric fluids for 5 min or other physiological fluids for 2 h(He et al., 2013b). To test the in vivo biological activity, nanoparticles were administered orally to mice (200 µg/kg) and 24h post administration reduced LPS-induced serum TNFα levels and reduced mRNA expression in liver, spleen and lung were observed(He et al., 2013b).

FIGREF54.text: Yin et al., 2013). With a siRNA (2'-O-methyl modified) dose of 200 µg/kg, oral delivery of these SSNPs reduced systemic TNFα expression in a mouse model of LPS-induced hepatic injury. Other chitosan nanoparticles were also tested for non-chemically modified siRNAs for oral use(Ballarin-Gonzalez et al., 2013). siRNA (78 µg) incorporated in chitosan nanoparticles was detected in the stomach, proximal and distal small intestines, and colon of mice 1 h and 5 h after oral gavage(Ballarin-Gonzalez et al., 2013). Nevertheless, low levels of naked siRNA were found in these organs at 1 h and were further reduced 5 h after dosing. At 1h , partial degradation products were observed in the proximal and distal regions of the small intestine and non-degraded siRNA was almost exclusively observed in the stomach(Ballarin-Gonzalez et al., 2013). Only chitosan nanoparticle-delivered siRNA was found to reach other tissues.

Aliquots of the digestion reaction were removed at 30, 60 min in gastric phase, and 5, 30and 75 min in intestinal phase for analysis:. Levels of surviving miRNAs were measured by qRT-PCR. FIGREF63.text: infant immune system, intestinal microbiota and several other biological functions(Andreas et al., 2015;  Ballard and Morrow, 2013). Among the ncRNAs identified in breast milk, miRNAs have been found to be particularly abundant(Gu et al., 2012;Zhou et al., 2012). Other types of RNAs have also been found in breast milk, including mRNAs(Hata et al., 2010; Izumi et al., 2012; Izumi et al., 2015), pre-miRNAs(Gu et al., 2012) and long ncRNAs(Karlsson et al., 2016). Several studies have identified miRNAs in human breast milk(Kosaka et al., 2010; Alsaweed et al., 2015; Alsaweed et al., 2016c, a), bovine milk(Hata et al., 2010)  and in milk of other species including pig(Gu et al., 2012; Chen et al., 2014;Sun J, 2017), panda and goat(Golan-Gerstl et al., 2017). It has been proposed that human milk miRNAs primarily originate from the mammary epithelium, while a smaller contribution is provided by maternal blood(Alsaweed et al., 2016c). Indeed, a considerably amount of mamary gland miRNAs were present in milk-derived microvesicles(Hata et al., 2010). Human milk miRNAs have been found to positively correlate with milk cellular and lipid content (Alsaweed et al., 2016a). In breast milk, miRNAs have been found in the cell fraction(Alsaweed et al., 2015), lipid fraction(Munch et al., 2013), exosomelike nanovesicles(Gu et al., 2012; Hata et al., 2010;Zhou et al., 2012), whey fraction(Izumi et al.,  2012)  and supernatant of whey after exosome isolation(Izumi et al., 2015). As far as their function, immune-related miRNAs are particularly abundant in human breast milk(Kosaka et al., 2010;, as well as the milk of cow(Hata et al., 2010;Sun et al., 2013), pig (Gu et al., 2012 Chen et  al., 2014;Sun J, 2017), goat(Mobuchon et al., 2015) and panda. Metabolism-related miRNAs were also common(Carney et al., 2017; Alsaweed et al., 2016a; Chen et al., 2014). Although a large amount of miRNAs has been identified in milk exosomes, it is important to note that several studies indicate that they are enriched by very few miRNA types. For example, 10 miRNAs account for www.efsa.europa.eu/publications 147 EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

FIGREF86.text: 2.3). Although the available literature suggests that dietary exogenous small plant ncRNAs seem to resist the harsh conditions of the GI tract in vitro and ex vivo, the percentage of miRNAs detected in the GI tract is low (≈1% after 75 min), varies in response to exposure time and depends on the specific small ncRNAs evaluated. By contrast, the literature describes several examples of the systemic effects of dietary plant-derived exogenous ncRNAs (section 3.3.3.1). However, there are also several reports that do not support the systemic effects and contradict the hypothesis of crosskingdom regulation (section 3.3.3.2). The available evidence also suggests that in vitro plant ncRNAs

TABREF22.text: To retrieve meaningful data for the food/feed risk assessment of ncRNAs-based GM plants, the title and abstract of all the identified studies were screened and their relevance assessed in order to gather information on the key questions identified for this subchapter:-Is there any evidence of a systemic effect of plant-origin exogenous ncRNAs when ingested? -Is there any evidence of negative or contradictory results regarding a possible systemic biological effect of dietary plant-origin ncRNAs when ingested? -Are exogenous ncRNAs quantitatively evaluated? -Are exogenous ncRNAs consumed in a sufficient amount to exert a systemic biological effect? -Does the literature describe the passage of plant-derived exogenous ncRNAs through other biological barriers (i.e. brain or placenta)?In vivo studies were mainly considered for this section. In accordance with the relevance of this topic (EFSA task 3), only plant-derived exogenous ncRNAs are evaluated. The literature search identified ≈30 review documents, position papers or comments regarding the possible systemic effects of dietary ncRNAs and their cross-kingdom regulation. To avoid bias, these documents were not evaluated or incorporated into the search.

TABREF51.text: No detectable amounts of unconjugated siRNAs were observed in tissue samples at the same time. Contrary to the conjugated siRNA, binding to serum albumin was absent in the unconjugated siRNA with a half-life of 6 min compared to the 95 min of the conjugated siRNA(Soutschek et al., 2004). It was observed that naked [ 18 F]-labelled siRNA start accumulating in the bladder shortly after the administration (<2 min), suggesting rapid renal excretion, while cationic liposome [ 18 F]-labelled siRNA complexes distribute to the lung(Hatanaka et al., 2010). After 60 min, small amounts of fluorescence (naked siRNAs) remained in the kidney but were not detected in other tissues, while liposome complexes were found to accumulate in the lungs(Hatanaka et al., 2010).

TABREF81.text: used chemically-synthesized exogenous miRNAs to enrich a dietary supplementation. However, whether a transgenic miRNA produced in a GM crop is bioavailable remains unknown. In this context, Yang et al., produced two transgenic Arabidopsis lines ectopically expressing unique miRNAs (see section 3.2.3.1) termed amiR-RICE and mmu-miR-146a. A feeding study was performed with male ICR mice (8-10 weeks old) fed a plant diet (5 g of plant diet contained 1 g dried plant) for 3 days before they were sacrificed. Daily plant material intake per mouse was equivalent to 3.3 g of fresh plant tissue. Levels of amiR-RICE and mmu-miR-146a reached 22.9 and 26.3 fmol/g of fresh weight, respectively. Transgenic miRNAs stability decreased in diets by approximately 10-fold (≈1 fmol/g) when they were incubated at room temperature. Moreover, after three days supplementation with the transgenic plant material, serum levels of transgenic miRNAs were negligible. Single ingestion of 400 pmol of synthetic amiR-RICE was not bioavailable. Furthermore, the www.efsa.europa.eu/publications 185 EFSA Supporting publication 2019:EN-1688

(Zhou et al., 2014) . Twenty female and ten male rats per group in the first generation (F0) were fed the different diets. Their pups, 20 weanling/female/group and 10 weanling/male/group were randomly selected as an F1 generation. The F2 generation was acquired by using the same procedure described above. At weaning, F3 generation rats were chosen, and 10 rats/sex/group provided the corresponding diets and observed for 13 weeks. No major differences in animal survival, health status, behaviour, body weight, food consumption, or reproductive capacity were observed with the different diets. Some statistically significant differences were observed in animals given the transgenic rice diets compared to those receiving the standard diet for certain clinical chemistry parameters, in certain generations (ALT, ALKP, LDH, cholesterol, HDLC, LDLC). These changes were not considered adverse or biologically significant (Zhou et al., 2014) . Moreover, no evidence of altered incidence or altered severity of background changes was observed in any organ or tissues of the rats fed the three diets (Zhou et al., 2014) . Although minor changes in the mean relative weight of epididimides in male F3 adults was observed in rats fed the rice diets compared to the control group, no difference was observed between the transgenic rice fed rats and their near-isogenic line controls, suggesting overall that the transgenic line was unlikely to cause any risk to rat health in reproduction or development, even when consumed for up to three generations (Zhou et al., 2014) . However, these studies did not evaluate any aspect related to RNAi.Heinemann et al. compared the history of risk assessment of GMOs producing dsRNAs in Australia, New Zealand and Brazil, with a focus on regulatory context (Heinemann et al., 2013) . The authors suggested some processes to properly assess the safety of dsRNA-producing GM plants before their release or marketing. These include i) bioinformatics analysis to identify any likely, unintended targets of the dsRNA in human and animals; ii) experimental procedures that would identify all new intended and unintended dsRNA molecules in the GM product; iii) testing animal and human cells in tissue cultures for a response to intended and unintended effects of dsRNAs from the product; iv) long-term testing on animals; and possibly v) clinical trials on human volunteers (Heinemann et al., 2013) . In response to this article, the regulatory agency Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) published a document addressing regulation of GM crops and foods developed using gene silencing (http://www.foodstandards.gov.au/consumer/gmfood/Pages/Response-to-Heinemann-et-al-on-theregulation-of-GM-crops-and-foods-developed-using-gene-silencing.aspx). This document criticised some of the comments of the above risk assessment review. Some key points included the lack of weight of scientific evidence (published up to 2013) to support the view that small dsRNAs in foods are likely to have adverse consequences in humans; the lack of a scientific basis for suggesting that small dsRNAs present in GM foods have different properties than naturally-occurring ones; or the adequate acknowledge of many barriers (in the uptake, distribution and targeting) during oral development of small dsRNA therapies, among others. The overall suggestion was that there was no need to consider additional studies as proposed by Heinemann et al. (2013) .Commentary documents reviewing scientific meetings in the context of RNAi technologies in agricultural biotechnology discuss some of the aspects reviewed in this document .Additional relevant documents of baseline information to support the risk assessment and environmental risk assessment of RNAi-based GM plants can be obtained from EFSA external scientific reports
